items.title: Substack is rolling out a TikTok-like video feed in its app
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Substack introduces a new scrollable video feed similar to TikTok, announced on March 31, 2025.
- The update is aimed at leveraging the potential gap left by TikTok amidst its uncertain future in the U.S.
- The platform previously allowed monetization of videos for creators and has been expanding its video features since 2022.
- The new video feed will showcase short-form videos under 10 minutes, with plans for longer content and podcast previews.
- Substack claims 82% of its top-earning writers are using multimedia, a rise from 50% in April 2024.
- With this feature, creators can expand their audience directly within Substack, aligning with the trend towards quick, snackable content across platforms.

items.title: EV truck maker Harbinger accuses Canoo of hiding assets in bankruptcy sale
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- Harbinger filed an objection to Canoo’s asset sale, alleging hidden assets.
- Canoo's CEO Anthony Aquila is purchasing the assets, with claims of unfair sales process.
- Harbinger argues that the sale favored Aquila and lacked proper marketing or appraisal.

items.title: Runway releases an impressive new video-generating AI model
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- AI startup Runway released Gen-4, a high-fidelity AI-powered video generator on March 31, 2025.
- Gen-4 can create consistent characters, locations, and maintain coherent environments across scenes without fine-tuning.
- Runway, backed by investors including Salesforce and Google, faces competition from OpenAI and others in the video generation space.
- The model provides continuity with visual references and allows users to generate dynamic videos with realistic motion.
- Runway is involved in a lawsuit over copyright claims regarding its training data and is raising funds that could value the company at $4 billion.
- A study indicated that 75% of production companies using AI have reduced jobs, predicting that over 100,000 U.S. entertainment jobs will be affected by 2026.

items.title: Trump says TikTok deal will come before April 5 deadline
items.summary:
- President Trump announced that a deal with TikTok’s parent company ByteDance will be finalized before the April 5 deadline.
- Trump noted significant interest from various potential buyers for TikTok.
- The deadline to ban TikTok was extended to April 5 after an executive order was signed in January.
- Private equity firm Blackstone is considering taking a small stake in TikTok’s U.S. operations and may join current non-Chinese shareholders in these efforts.
- Trump indicated he might extend the deadline again if a deal isn’t achieved in time.

items.title: ChatGPT: Everything you need to know about the AI-powered chatbot
items.summary:
- ChatGPT launched in November 2022, quickly gaining 300 million weekly active users.
- In 2024, OpenAI partnered with Apple and released GPT-4o with voice capabilities and text-to-video model Sora.
- OpenAI experienced executive departures and faced lawsuits over copyright issues.
- In 2025, OpenAI seeks to maintain competitiveness against Chinese companies like DeepSeek, while planning a major data center project and large funding round. 
- Notable updates in March 2025 include removing restrictions on image generation and adopting Anthropic's Model Context Protocol for AI responses.
- OpenAI expected revenue growth to $12.7 billion in 2025 with a new funding round approaching.

items.title: Streaming service Plex rolls out a revamped mobile app
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Plex has released an updated version of its mobile app on March 31, 2025.
- The redesign includes a new user experience, reorganized navigation, and a dedicated Watchlist section.
- Enhanced media features are added, including richer title artwork and revamped detail pages for movies and shows.
- The updated mobile app will be followed by an update for TV platforms.
- Core users can personalize their experience with favorites and improved media library tabs.
- The Watchlist feature is now prominently placed in the navigation menu for better access.

items.title: Last Chance to Save $300+ on TechCrunch All Stage Passes
items.summary:
- Less than 24 hours left to save over $300 on TechCrunch All Stage founder and investor passes.
- The event takes place on July 15 at SoWa Power Station in Boston, where founders can gain insights and investors can discover new opportunities.
- Discounts end at 11:59 p.m. PT, making it urgent for interested attendees to secure tickets promptly.

items.title: Manus launches paid subscription plans and a mobile app
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Manus AI launches two subscription plans starting at $39 per month.
- The lower-cost plan includes 3,900 credits and allows running two tasks simultaneously, while the premium plan offers 19,900 credits and five simultaneous tasks for $199 per month.
- Manus also released an iOS app and upgraded its AI backend to Anthropic’s Claude 3.7 Sonnet.

items.title: Temporal lands $146 million at a flat valuation, eyes agentic AI expansion
items.author: Anna Heim, Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Seattle-based [Temporal](https://temporal.io/) raised $146 million to expand into AI and agentic AI microservices.
- The investment will focus on R&D, including enhancing the new feature Nexus, and increasing sales and marketing efforts.
- The funding round was led by Tiger Global, and previous investors include Index Ventures and Sequoia Capital. Total funding for Temporal has reached $350 million.
- The company's valuation post-funding is approximately $1.72 billion, a slight increase from a previous flat valuation of $1.5 billion.
- Temporal’s platform, which assists in managing microservices, has seen a 4.4x revenue increase over the past 18 months, with 183,000 active users and 2,500 customers in its enterprise service.

items.title: Amazon unveils Nova Act, an AI agent that can control a web browser
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Amazon introduced Nova Act, a general-purpose AI agent for web browser control.
- Launched alongside the Nova Act SDK for developers to create agent prototypes.
- Originates from Amazon’s AGI lab, co-led by former OpenAI researchers.
- Nova Act will enhance features in the upcoming Alexa+.
- The toolkit enables developers to automate tasks like ordering food or making reservations.
- Nova Act outperforms competitors in specific internal tests but hasn't been tested with common evaluations.
- Aims to create superintelligent AI by innovating agent technology.

items.title: IPO-bound Chime hopes to boost growth by paying higher interest rates
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Chime offers a 3.75% APY for customers who direct deposit their paychecks into savings or checking accounts.
- The national average savings account yield is 0.61% APY.
- Chime aims to enhance customer retention and currently has 7 million customers and $1.5 billion in annual revenue.
- The company filed for an IPO with a valuation of $25 billion and has raised a total of $2.65 billion.
- New features include a redesigned app, cashback offers, and dedicated customer support.
- Chime began offering a credit card to help users build credit without requiring direct deposits.

items.title: This isn’t the Matrix
items.summary:
- Jeffrey Goldberg, editor-in-chief of The Atlantic, was added to a Signal chat with 17 U.S. government officials discussing airstrikes in Yemen.
- National security adviser Mike Waltz claimed Goldberg's number was 'sucked in' from another contact.
- Goldberg refuted this, stating phone numbers do not transfer without direct entry.
- Signal's president Meredith Whittaker highlighted the need for understanding secure messaging principles amidst increased scrutiny of the app.

items.title: Apple reportedly revamping Health app to add an AI coach
items.author: Mark Gurman
items.summary:
- Apple is enhancing its Health app to introduce an AI coach for health advice.
- The AI coach aims to provide users with guidance on improving their health, potentially launching in spring or summer of 2026.
- Development follows earlier reports from 2023, with the new features expected to debut with iOS 19.4.
- The AI will use data from medical devices and include food tracking capabilities.
- The project is currently in training phases with data from staff doctors, and more professionals will contribute health-related content.

items.title: Perplexity CEO denies having financial issues, says no IPO before 2028
items.author: Aravind Srinivas
items.summary:
- Perplexity CEO Aravind Srinivas reassures users on Reddit regarding financial stability and product complaints.
- Response to user theories claiming financial struggles and cost-cutting measures.
- Srinivas emphasizes growth in revenue, stating no IPO plans before 2028.

items.title: China Miéville says we shouldn’t blame science fiction for its bad readers
items.summary:
- China Miéville reflects on his literary career 25 years after 'Perdido Street Station.'
- He emphasizes that science fiction should not be blamed for societal issues faced by tech billionaires.
- Miéville argues that science fiction reflects current sociological contexts, not the future.
- He criticizes the tech industry's interpretation of sci-fi as blueprints for the future, calling it misguided.
- Miéville explains the tension between subculture success and dilution in quality over time.

items.title: The hottest AI models, what they do, and how to use them
items.summary:
- AI models are being rapidly developed by major companies and startups, leading to overwhelming choices for users.
- An overview of advanced AI models released since 2024 is provided, detailing their uses and features.
- Key AI models released in 2025 include Google Gemini 2.5, ChatGPT-4o image generator, Stability AI's Stable Virtual Camera, Cohere's Aya Vision, among others, each with specific capabilities and access requirements.
- Most models require subscriptions, with prices ranging from $20 to $200 per month depending on features and capabilities.
- The article emphasizes ongoing updates to this list to reflect new launches and developments in AI technology.

items.title: Beyond Bluesky: These are the apps building social experiences on the AT Protocol
items.summary:
- Bluesky, which now has over 33 million users, is based on the AT Protocol, inspiring numerous applications for an open social web.
- The first conference for the AT Protocol, ATmosphere, was held in Seattle, addressing future developments and challenges.
- Notable applications being developed include Flashes (an Instagram alternative), Spark (a video-first app), and Pinksky (another Instagram competitor).
- Streamplace, a livestream service, was created as part of this new ecosystem, focusing on high-quality video and consent management.
- Graze and Surf are tools that allow users to build and customize feeds, promoting a more personalized digital experience.

items.title: Data centers love solar: Here’s a comprehensive guide to deals over 100 megawatts
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Tech companies are rapidly expanding data centers, increasing power demand by 100% by 2029.
- Solar power is experiencing significant growth with 12 major deals since 2025, each adding over 100 MW.
- Major companies involved include Meta (200 MW with Engie, 595 MW with Zelestra), Microsoft (389 MW with EDP), and Amazon (476 MW hybrid project).
- Solar's average completion time is around 18 months, making it attractive compared to other energy sources.
- Growing interest in solar is driven by the need for sustainable power as tech firms embrace AI technologies.

items.title: Just 2 days to secure your founder or investor pass with $300+ off for TechCrunch All Stage
items.summary:
- Less than 48 hours left to secure a $300+ discount for [TechCrunch All Stage](https://techcrunch.com/events/techcrunch-all-stage-2025/?utm_source=tc&utm_medium=post&utm_campaign=tcallstage2025&utm_content=earlybird&promo=post_eb2days_03302025&display=) founder and investor passes.
- Rates increase on March 31 at 11:59 p.m. PT; the event takes place on July 15 at SoWa Power Station in Boston.
- The event offers insights for founders and key networking opportunities for investors.

items.title: Sam Altman firing drama detailed in new book excerpt
items.summary:
- Excerpt from the book "The Optimist: Sam Altman, OpenAI, and the Race to Invent the Future" reveals details about Altman's firing in 2023.
- OpenAI board concerned about issues like the OpenAI Startup Fund, personally owned by Altman.
- Evidence of alleged toxic behavior collected by co-founder Ilya Sutskever and CTO Mira Murati, including screenshots of misleading claims.
- Altman was briefly ousted, leading to employee protests for his return; he subsequently returned to his position.

items.title: Amazon shakes up streaming leadership team
Elon Musk’s xAI buys X
items.author: Karyne Levy
items.summary:
- xAI acquired X in an all-stock transaction valued at $80 billion for xAI and $33 billion for X.
- Elon Musk announced the acquisition on X, stating the goal is to combine data, models, compute, distribution, and talent.
- The article covers other tech news including company layoffs, fraud allegations against startups, and new product announcements from Apple and Nintendo.

items.title: Elon Musk says xAI acquired X
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's AI startup, xAI, acquired his social media platform X in an all-stock deal.
- The acquisition values xAI at $80 billion and X at $33 billion, reflecting a significant decline from Musk's prior purchase price of $44 billion in 2022.
- X has over 600 million active users, which gives xAI a large consumer base and access to valuable training data for AI development.

items.title: CoreWeave co-founder explains how a closet of crypto-mining GPUs led to a $1.5B IPO
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- CoreWeave priced its IPO at $40, below the expected range, and opened with a valuation of $14 billion, raising $1.5 billion on Day 1.
- The IPO marks the largest AI-related listing to date and the biggest U.S. tech IPO since 2021.
- The company evolved from a large Ethereum mining operation to AI training, partnering with EleutherAI and attracting significant investments, including a $12 billion deal with OpenAI.

items.title: A look at Intel Capital before the 34-year-old firm strikes out on its own
items.summary:
- Intel Capital announced plans to spin out from Intel in January 2025.
- Founded nearly 35 years ago, it is regarded as one of the first corporate venture capital firms.
- The firm has invested over $20 billion across 1,800 companies and has achieved more than 700 startup exits.
- Discussions about spinning out became serious in early 2024 and were influenced by a strong track record and recent successful exits, such as Astera Labs, which went public at a $5.5 billion valuation.
- The spinout is expected to be completed by Q3 2025, with Intel remaining as an anchor investor.
- The new firm will continue to focus on investing in early-stage startups in AI, cloud, devices, and frontier tech.

items.title: Here are Africa’s biggest startups based on valuation
items.summary:
- In 2023, funding for African startups exceeded $2 billion, returning to pre-pandemic levels.
- A decline in mega-deals led investors to focus on sustainable business models and profitability pathways.
- High-profile closures impacted companies like Copia and Gro Intelligence, which had previously raised significant funding.
- The startup ecosystem is experiencing challenges even affecting growth-stage companies.
- Strategic mergers occurred, such as between Wasoko and MaxAB, to streamline operations.
- Notable startups such as Moniepoint, Moove, and TymeBank received investments from leading firms like Uber and Google, boosting their valuations.
- The article highlights the current state of billion-dollar ventures and potential future unicorns in Africa.

items.title: Only 3 days left to save $300+ on investor and founder tickets for TechCrunch All Stage
items.summary:
- Last chance to secure Early Bird pricing for [TechCrunch All Stage](https://techcrunch.com/events/techcrunch-all-stage-2025/?utm_source=tc&utm_medium=post&utm_campaign=tcallstage2025&utm_content=earlybird&utm_protocol=post_eb3days_03292025&utm_display=) tickets before March 31, 11:59 p.m. PT.  
- Save up to $320; event will be held on July 15 at SoWa Power Station in Boston.  
- Approximately 1,200 founders and VCs expected to attend to facilitate networking and investment opportunities.  
- Founders gain insights from top VCs and experts through breakout sessions.  
- Growth-stage founders will learn about sustainable scaling, Series C funding, and IPO preparation.  
- Hands-on roundtables will allow for in-depth discussions and networking.  
- Participants can watch live pitches and receive expert feedback.  
- Nearly sold-out exhibit tables available for showcasing innovations.  
- Explore networking events and sponsorship opportunities.  
- Don't forget to [subscribe](https://techcrunch.com/newsletters/event-updates/) for updates on TechCrunch events.

items.title: Tesla Takedown Protesters Plan Global Day of Action Amid Rising Tensions
items.summary:
- The "Tesla Takedown" organizers are encouraging protests worldwide on March 29.
- Activists aim to peacefully object to Elon Musk's role in government spending cuts.
- Rising tensions have led to accusations of equating peaceful protests with vandalism and terrorism.
- President Trump labeled attacks on Tesla as 'domestic terrorism' and threatens severe actions against organizers.
- Protesters focus on financial pressure, urging people to sell Teslas and stock to lower Musk's wealth.
- March 29 protests are set across multiple states and countries.
- Activists emphasize their nonviolent approach despite fears of severe crackdowns from law enforcement.

items.title: Javice found guilty of defrauding JPMorgan in $175M startup purchase
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Charlie Javice, founder of Frank, was found guilty of defrauding JPMorgan by inflating customer numbers.
- The jury ruled Javice fabricated the customer list, initially claiming 4 million customers when actual figures were 300,000.
- Javice hired a math professor to create fake data to mislead JPMorgan during acquisition discussions.
- Sentencing is expected in August, with potential decades in prison for Javice, now 32.

items.title: ‘Tesla Takedown’ protesters are planning a global day of action on March 29, and things might get ugly
items.summary:
- ‘Tesla Takedown’ organizers are planning a global day of action on March 29, encouraging protests outside Tesla locations.
- Protests are a response to Elon Musk's influence in slashing government spending; organizers aim to pressure people to stop buying Teslas.
- Tensions are rising with prominent figures like President Trump labeling attacks on Tesla as 'domestic terrorism'.
- The movement emphasizes nonviolence, contrasting with claims equating peaceful protests with vandalism.
- Over 213 protests are scheduled worldwide, including locations in the US and Europe.
- Activists warn of potential law enforcement crackdowns on peaceful demonstrators due to rising tensions in rhetoric and media coverage.

items.title: Elon Musk says xAI acquired X
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's xAI has acquired social media platform X (formerly Twitter) in an all-stock deal.
- The acquisition values xAI at $80 billion and X at $33 billion, factoring in $12 billion in debt.
- X, which Musk purchased for $44 billion in 2022, has more than 600 million daily active users.
- The deal integrates data and technologies of xAI and X, suggesting deeper collaboration of their products.

items.title: Fintech VC powerhouse Frank Rotman stepping down from QED Investors to found his own startups
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Frank Rotman will transition to a partner emeritus role at QED Investors by the end of the year.
- He plans to focus on founding his own startups, starting with one in the music industry.
- QED has $4 billion in assets under management and invests exclusively in financial technology companies.
- Rotman will maintain a part-time advisory role at QED and plans to write a book on startup and VC frameworks.
- Amias Gerety will be promoted to lead QED’s U.S. investment team.

items.title: Nintendo announces ‘Legend of Zelda’ movie release date via new app
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Nintendo announced that the live-action ‘The Legend of Zelda’ movie will premiere on March 26, 2027.
- The announcement was made through the new app, Nintendo Today!, to encourage downloads.
- The app provides daily news about Nintendo games and customizable preferences for franchises.
- The strategy follows the success of the ‘Super Mario Bros’ movie, which grossed $1.3 billion with a $100 million budget.
- ‘Breath of the Wild’ has sold over 34 million copies, demonstrating the franchise's popularity.

items.title: Inside the Rivian Skunkworks Program and Trump's Economic Moves for Tesla
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's ally Trump imposed 25% tariffs on all cars imported to the US, impacting costs for new and used cars.
- Trump’s tariffs are seen as beneficial for Tesla, which is led by Musk, a supporter during Trump's presidential campaign.
- Rivian is launching a new micromobility startup called Also, with $105 million funding from Eclipse Ventures and minority ownership from Rivian's founder RJ Scaringe.

items.title: Breast pump startup Willow acquires assets of Elvie as UK women’s health pioneer moves into administration
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Willow, based in San Francisco, is acquiring Elvie, a London startup, as Elvie enters administration.
- Elvie has raised over $186 million since its inception, with a peak valuation of $241 million.
- Willow is absorbing Elvie’s existing business, which includes approximately 170 employees, but some may not transition due to notice periods.
- The women’s health market, valued at $60 billion, faces challenges including competition from cheaper products and lack of exit opportunities for startups.
- Willow aims to demonstrate that femtech products can be profitable businesses despite market difficulties.

items.title: Startups Weekly: Mercury more than doubled its valuation, and other news
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- Digital banking startup Mercury raised $300 million in Series C funding, doubling its valuation to $3.5 billion.
- Terrestrial Energy went public via SPAC, expecting to net $280 million; it focuses on small modular nuclear reactors.
- Vertical farming company Plenty filed for bankruptcy after raising nearly $1 billion in funding.
- Block laid off 931 employees, as revealed in a leaked email.
- Nvidia is reportedly in talks to acquire Lepton AI, while FuriosaAI rejected an $800 million offer from Meta.

items.title: 4 days left to lock in $300+ savings for investor and founder tickets for TechCrunch All Stage
items.summary:
- 4 days remaining to save over $300 on Founder and Investor Passes for [TechCrunch All Stage](https://techcrunch.com/events/techcrunch-all-stage-2025/?utm_source=tc&utm_medium=post&utm_campaign=tcallstage2025&utm_content=earlybird&promo=post_eb4days_03272025&utm_display=).
- Event takes place on July 15 at SoWa Power Station, Boston, MA, expecting 1,200 founders and VCs.
- Early bird offer ends March 31 at 11:59 p.m. PT.
- The event includes breakout sessions for early-stage and growth-stage founders to engage with VCs and scaling experts.
- Networking opportunities between founders and investors will be available throughout the event.

items.title: Again and again, NSO Group’s customers keep getting their spyware operations caught
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Amnesty International published a report on attempted hacks against two Serbian journalists using NSO Group's Pegasus spyware.
- The journalists received suspicious phishing texts that led to a domain linked to NSO’s infrastructure.
- Researchers are adept at identifying NSO Group's spyware, indicating a failure of NSO and its clients to avoid detection.
- NSO Group has been implicated in targeting activists and journalists, with over 130 identified victims globally since 2016.
- Apple's efforts to counter spyware have led to notifications sent to numerous victims worldwide, prompting them to seek help from various nonprofits against attacks.

items.title: OpenAI peels back ChatGPT’s safeguards around image creation
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- OpenAI launched a new image generator in ChatGPT that creates Studio Ghibli-style images.
- Revised content moderation policies now allow the generation of images depicting public figures and controversial symbols.
- OpenAI aims for a more nuanced approach to handle sensitive content while allowing user opt-out options.
- ChatGPT can now fulfill requests related to physical characteristics and generate images with styles of creative studios.
- Recent changes may impact AI content moderation discussions and regulatory scrutiny under the Trump administration.

items.title: Lucid to ramp customer deliveries for Gravity SUV by end of April
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Lucid Motors plans to resume customer deliveries for its Gravity SUV by the end of April 2025.
- The Gravity is Lucid's second vehicle and first SUV, following the Lucid Air sedan.
- Orders for the seven-seater SUV opened in November 2024, with employee deliveries starting in December.
- Interim CEO Marc Winterhoff stated they are nearly finished with production and will begin customer deliveries soon.
- The Gravity SUV has an EPA range estimate of 450 miles and is priced at $94,900, featuring advanced battery technology for high performance.

items.title: Zuckerberg's Reflections on 'The Social Network' Experience
items.summary:
- Zuckerberg expressed that watching 'The Social Network' was a strange experience due to portrayal inaccuracies.
- He mentioned the film's narrative incorrectly suggested his motivations were centered around dating, while he was already with Priscilla when Facebook started.
- Zuckerberg organized a company viewing of the film, aware that employees would be interested.
- He criticized the myth-making around his early projects, specifically addressing links between Facemash and Facebook, denying that Facemash was a precursor to Facebook.
- He has become more conscious about his clothing style since then, as showcased by him wearing a T-shirt that Jesse Eisenberg wore in the film.

items.title: WhatsApp users can now add songs to their Status updates
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- WhatsApp launched a new feature allowing users to add brief music clips to their Status updates, starting March 28, 2025.
- Users can select from millions of songs, sharing clips up to 15 seconds for photos and 60 seconds for videos.
- The music feature is similar to Instagram's but offers end-to-end encryption, ensuring only friends can view the shared songs.
- The rollout of this new feature is underway globally, with expanded availability expected in the coming weeks.

items.title: YC-backed Taxo raises $5M to slash healthcare admin with its AI ‘reasoning engine’
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- British doctor Ahmed Kerwan founded Taxo to reduce healthcare administrative burden using AI.
- Taxo's app facilitates tasks like insurance prior authorizations, patient intake, and medical billing.
- The AI ‘reasoning engine’ increases prior authorization approval rates to 98%, significantly above the industry average of 80%.
- Taxo recently closed a $5 million seed round led by Y Combinator, General Catalyst, and Character Capital.
- Founded in 2024, Taxo achieved $1 million ARR within six months and currently serves around 15 customers.

items.title: Nikola founder Trevor Milton pardoned by Trump
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Trevor Milton, founder of Nikola, has been pardoned by President Trump after being convicted of fraud.
- Milton was convicted in October 2022 of securities fraud and wire fraud, leading to a four-year prison sentence in December 2023.
- The pardon follows Nikola's recent Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing as the company attempts to sell its business by mid-April.

items.title: Mozilla patches Firefox bug ‘exploited in the wild’, similar to bug attacking Chrome
items.summary:
- Mozilla has released an update for Firefox addressing a security bug tracked as CVE-2025-2857, which was actively exploited.
- The updated version is Firefox 136.0.4, which follows a similar pattern to a recent bug patched in Google Chrome.
- The bug allowed potential escape from Firefox’s sandbox, impacting other browsers like the Tor Browser, which also received a patch.
- Kaspersky's Boris Larin linked these exploits to targeted attacks on journalists and institutions in Russia.

items.title: Google rolls out user choice billing on Google Play in the UK
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Google is launching user choice billing in the U.K. on March 29 for non-game developers.
- Developers can use alternative billing options but must also retain Google Play's billing system.
- Developers opting for alternative billing receive a 4% discount on fees paid to Google, which typically charges up to 30%.
- This move responds to a 2022 CMA investigation into competitive practices in app billing.
- Google previously proposed this billing choice to settle antitrust issues raised by the CMA.
- User choice billing is already operational in countries like the U.S., India, and Australia.

items.title: Krafton acquires controlling stake in Indian gaming studio Nautilus Mobile for $14M
items.summary:
- Krafton acquired a controlling stake of over 75% in Nautilus Mobile for $14 million in cash.
- Nautilus Mobile, founded in 2013 and based in Pune, is known for its Real Cricket franchise.
- The acquisition aims to strengthen Krafton's mobile cricket games strategy in India, a key market with growing demand for such titles.
- The deal is set to close by the end of March 2025, with Nautilus continuing to operate independently.
- Krafton plans to explore new gaming genres and expand Nautilus’ presence beyond India.
- India’s mobile gaming market is projected to grow from $640 million in 2023 to $1.1 billion by 2028.
- Krafton has previously invested $5.4 million in Nautilus and plans further collaboration for game development.
- JetSynthesys, which owned Nautilus previously, will remain a minority investor and partner in eSports initiatives.

items.title: Open source devs are fighting AI crawlers with cleverness and vengeance
items.summary:
- AI web-crawling bots are seen as a major nuisance by software developers, particularly in open source.
- Developers like Xe Iaso created tools like Anubis to combat aggressive AI crawlers that ignore robots.txt files.
- Anubis uses a proof-of-work challenge to distinguish between human users and bots.
- FOSS projects are more vulnerable due to their open nature and fewer resources compared to commercial sites.
- Some developers have resorted to extreme measures, including banning traffic from entire countries to mitigate crawler interference.
- Cloudflare and other companies are offering tools to confuse and slow down AI crawlers.
- The community is sharing clever ideas to trap crawlers into consuming irrelevant content.

items.title: Certification platform Certiverse nabs $11M series A led by Cherryrock
items.author: Ruben Garcia, Pablo Meyer, Frederico Lopez
items.summary:
- Certiverse raised $11 million Series A led by Cherryrock Capital.
- Founded in 2023, the platform allows organizations to develop certification exams at reduced costs.
- Clients include The Linux Foundation and HashiCorp, with significant savings on exam development costs.
- CEO Ruben Garcia has experience in the certification industry, having co-founded Innovative Exams.
- Certiverse aims to automate exam creation and expand its client base significantly with the new funding.

items.title: Trump’s auto tariffs are a gift to Tesla
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- President Trump announced a 25% tariff on all imported cars and certain auto parts.
- The tariffs could increase the costs of new and used cars but may benefit Tesla, as it builds all its vehicles for the North American market in the U.S.
- Tesla imports 20-30% of components, which will still incur tariffs, but it is better positioned than competitors like Ford and GM, who manufacture many vehicles abroad.
- The tariff could lead to higher prices for other EVs while Tesla could keep prices lower with potential new models.
